item.title: Trump Suggests U.S. Could Take Action Against More Countries
item.description: On Air Force One, President Trump threatened Colombia and its president, described Cuba as “ready to fall” and reasserted his desire to acquire Greenland.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: Asked on Air Force One on Sunday whether his administration would target Colombia, President Trump replied, “It sounds good to me.”

item.title: Cuba Says 32 of Its Citizens Died in Venezuela, Including Military Personnel
item.description: President Miguel Díaz-Canel said the casualties were from Cuba’s armed forces or interior ministry. The country is a longstanding ally of Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.media:description: Antennas hit by U.S. airstrikes in Caracas, Venezuela, on Sunday.

item.title: Venezuela’s New Leader Calls for Dialogue and ‘Coexistence’ With U.S.
item.description: Acting President Delcy Rodríguez struck a more diplomatic tone than she had on Saturday, inviting the United States to “work together on a cooperative agenda.”
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles
item.media:description: Delcy Rodríguez, now Venezuela’s acting president, in Caracas last year.

item.title: Delcy Rodríguez, Venezuela’s New Leader, Faces Big Test
item.description: Delcy Rodríguez is the torchbearer of a government whose revolutionary roots are in disarray. She must appease constituencies who loathe U.S. meddling while fielding Washington’s demands.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero, Isayen Herrera and María Victoria Fermín
item.media:description: A photo of Venezuela’s new leader, Delcy Rodríguez, from August. With her were Foreign Minister Yvan Gil, left, and a Venezuelan lawyer, Larry Devoe.

item.title: Iran and Venezuela found kinship in anti-American ideology and in evading U.S. sanctions.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: Ebrahim Raisi, left, and Nicolás Maduro delivering a joint statement at Miraflores Presidential Palace in Caracas, Venezuela, in 2023 when they were the leaders of Iran and Venezuela.

item.title: Maduro’s Capture Shows Trump’s Goal to Dominate the Americas
item.description: Latin America was already struggling with how to handle President Trump’s interventions in the region. Then he attacked Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.category: Community of Latin American and Caribbean States
item.media:description: Jesus Linares, 48, and Reggie Carrero, 52, in a damaged apartment on Sunday in Catia La Mar, Venezuela, after strikes conducted by the U.S. military as part of the operation to capture Nicolás Maduro.

item.title: Exiled Venezuelans Celebrate Maduro’s Downfall, but Are Wary
item.description: “I had utterly lost hope,” said one Venezuelan who has lived in exile from his country for seven years.
item.dc:creator: Max Bearak
item.media:credit: Federico Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: Venezuelans took to the streets of Cúcuta, Colombia, to celebrate on Saturday.

item.title: Satellite Imagery Reveals Damage to Venezuelan Base Where Maduro Was Captured
item.description: Before-and-after imagery released on Sunday shows that at least five buildings at the complex were destroyed by U.S. forces.
item.dc:creator: Sanjana Varghese
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Behind the Scenes of Our Nicolás Maduro Front Page
item.description: After President Trump’s surprise ouster of Venezuela’s authoritarian leader, a team of New York Times editors set to work redoing the front page.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Bahr

item.title: ‘They’re Invading Us’: The U.S. Attack Viewed From Venezuelans’ Cellphones
item.description: The videos, filmed on cellphones by people mainly in Caracas and La Guaira, showed the exact moments in which the U.S. air and ground incursion played out in real time.
item.dc:creator: Emiliano Rodríguez Mega, Arijeta Lajka and McKinnon de Kuyper

item.title: Trump Says U.S. Is ‘In Charge’ of Venezuela, While Rubio Stresses Coercing It
item.description: The secretary of state said that a military “quarantine” on some oil exports would stay in place to put pressure on the country’s acting leadership.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio at a news conference with President Trump at Mar-a-Lago, the president’s private estate and club in Palm Beach, Fla., on Saturday morning.

item.title: U.S. Has No Troops in Venezuela, Defense Department Says
item.description: A significant buildup of U.S. soldiers and ships will remain in the Caribbean and surrounding countries to protect “our interests the region,” the Joint Chiefs chairman said.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump suggested there would be a “second wave” of military action in Venezuela if the United States ran into resistance.

item.title: Here’s the latest.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev, Jack Nicas, Edward Wong and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: How Trump Fixed On a Maduro Loyalist as Venezuela’s New Leader
item.description: Nicolás Maduro balked at a gilded exile. U.S. officials then saw a more pliant option in his vice president, Delcy Rodríguez, known for stabilizing Venezuela’s economy.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev, Tyler Pager, Simon Romero and Julie Turkewitz
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Brittainy Newman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Vice President Delcy Rodríguez of Venezuela, now the country’s interim leader, speaking at the United Nations General Assembly in New York in 2019.

item.title: Why Trump Removed Venezuela’s Maduro
item.description: David E. Sanger, our national security correspondent, describes the implications of President Trump’s launching of the attack that captured the Venezuelan president, and Trump’s declaration that the United States would “run the country.”
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger, Alexandra Ostasiewicz, Leila Medina and June Kim

item.title: After U.S. Attack, Venezuelans Worry About Political Stability
item.description: Nicolás Maduro was unpopular. But his abrupt removal has created deep uncertainty, alarming even those who opposed him.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib and Frances Robles
item.media:description: In Caracas, the streets were silent on Saturday, save for a few small demonstrations organized by the government to protest Nicolás Maduro’s ouster.

item.title: Maduro’s Final Plea: ‘No War. Yes Peace.’
item.description: Days before he was captured, Nicolás Maduro expounded on his precarious position — and tried to offer an olive branch to President Trump.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nicolás Maduro at a rally in Caracas last month.

item.title: Maduro’s Capture Prompts Protests and Celebrations in U.S. Cities
item.description: Opponents of the U.S. intervention in Venezuela called it illegal. Supporters celebrated the ouster of Nicolás Maduro, the country’s authoritarian president.
item.dc:creator: Robert Chiarito, Adam Sella and Raúl Vilchis
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Demonstrators marching toward the Trump Tower in Chicago on Saturday.

item.title: In Wake of U.S. Strike, Venezuelan Paramilitaries Are Little Seen
item.description: As the armed civilian groups often used to suppress protests kept a low profile, the role they might play in the country’s new situation remained unclear.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles
item.media:description: Armed civilians in La Guaira, Venezuela, after the U.S. strikes in the country on Saturday. The groups known as colectivos, whose function is often to suppress protesters, stayed mostly out of sight on Saturday.

item.title: The U.S. Indictment of Maduro Cites Cocaine Smuggling. Venezuela’s Role in the Trade Is Believed to Be Modest.
item.description: Experts have said that Venezuela is not a major drug producer but a minor cocaine transit country, with most of the cocaine flowing through it headed to Europe.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Glatsky and Annie Correal
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nicolás Maduro making a speech in Caracas last year.

item.title: Trump Plunges the U.S. Into a New Era of Risk in Venezuela
item.description: President Trump opened a new chapter in American nation building by toppling Venezuela’s leader and promising U.S. intervention in running its affairs.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Tyler Pager
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times
item.media:description: People in Doral, Fla., celebrating the capture of President Nicolás Maduro by U.S. forces on Saturday.

item.title: Venezuelan Official Says at Least 40 People Were Killed in U.S. Attack
item.description: The official said the dead included civilians and military personnel. At least one of the civilians was killed in a U.S. airstrike outside of Caracas, according to her family.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Wilman Gonzalez carries the furniture he managed to save from his home in Catia La Mar, Venezuela, after it got blown up during the airstrikes. His aunt, Rosa Gonzalez, 80, who lived with him, died during the strike.

item.title: A Pardon and a Prosecution in New York Show Trump’s Personal Geopolitics
item.description: The facts in the cases of Nicolás Maduro and Juan Orlando Hernández are strikingly similar. The men’s fates are not.
item.dc:creator: Jonah E. Bromwich
item.media:description: When President Juan Orlando Hernández of Honduras was extradited in 2022, his nation’s capital celebrated. President Trump pardoned him last month anyway.

item.title: In Toppling Maduro, Trump Risks Blowback from ‘America First’ Base
item.description: President Trump’s pledge that the United States would “run” Venezuela for an indefinite period showed he is willing to enter foreign conflicts he once promised to end.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs and David E. Sanger
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump speaking about the attack on Venezuela from his private club and residence Mar-a-Lago in Palm Beach, Fla., on Saturday.

item.title: Trump Long Wanted to ‘Take the Oil.’ He Says He’ll Do It in Venezuela.
item.description: The White House had pointed to drug trafficking and migration as reasons to crack down on Nicolás Maduro. But oil emerged as central to President Trump.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: Workers of the Venezuelan state oil company PDVSA in September. There was little immediate clarity on Saturday as to how the White House envisions the United States profiting from Venezuela’s oil.

item.title: Maduro and His Wife to Be Arraigned in Manhattan Federal Court
item.description: Nicolás Maduro, Venezuela’s president, and his wife, Cilia Flores, will make their first appearance on Monday in a New York City courthouse, the site of other high-profile proceedings.
item.dc:creator: William K. Rashbaum and Benjamin Weiser
item.media:description: The trials of many notorious defendants have taken place at the courthouse in Lower Manhattan where Nicolás Maduro and his wife, Cilia Flores, will be arraigned on Monday.

item.title: Who Is Cilia Flores, Maduro’s Wife, and Why Was She Captured Alongside Him?
item.description: Operating largely from the shadows, Ms. Flores, the first lady of Venezuela, helped consolidate Mr. Maduro’s rule while controlling the judiciary and amassing wealth through corruption, experts say.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Glatsky
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela and his wife, Cilia Flores, during a rally in Caracas, Venezuela, in December. They were both captured and taken to the United States on Jan. 3.

item.title: How Democrats Are Hitting Trump Over Nicolás Maduro’s Ouster
item.description: Some of the nation’s most influential Democrats condemned the move as unjustified and argued that the president was trying to distract from his domestic challenges.
item.dc:creator: Kellen Browning
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, Democrat of New York, was one of several prominent Democrats who criticized President Trump’s order to strike Venezuela and capture its president, Nicolás Maduro.

item.title: With the President Gone, Venezuelans Race to Stock Up on Food
item.description: People hit grocery stores on Saturday as they anxiously waited for word on what would happen next.
item.dc:creator: Sheyla Urdaneta and Frances Robles
item.media:description: Residents wait in line at a supermarket in Caracas, Venezuela, on Saturday. Venezuelans crowded stores after the U.S. strikes in the country and the removal of its president, Nicolás Maduro.

item.title: Zohran Mamdani Called President Trump to Criticize Venezuela Strikes
item.description: Mayor Zohran Mamdani of New York accused President Trump of violating international law. It was the first time he had criticized the president since their White House meeting.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Fandos and Maia Coleman
item.media:credit: Heather Khalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: During a news conference on Saturday, Mayor Zohran Mamdani said he had spoken to President Trump and criticized the capture of President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela.

item.title: Delcy Rodríguez, Venezuela’s New Leader, Boasts Leftist Credentials
item.description: The interim leader is known for hewing to left-wing ideals, facing sanctions by the U.S. and European Union and building bridges with Venezuela’s business community.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Vice President Delcy Rodríguez of Venezuela, who was sworn in as the country’s interim leader on Saturday, during an interview in Caracas, Venezuela, in September.

item.title: Trump administration declines to back Venezuela’s opposition leader.
item.dc:creator: Julie Turkewitz and Genevieve Glatsky
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: María Corina Machado, Venezuela’s leading opposition figure, at a rally during the country’s presidential election in 2024.

item.title: Before Nicolás Maduro, There Was Manuel Noriega
item.description: The Venezuelan leader is now in U.S. custody. Decades earlier, the United States deposed the strongman who led Panama.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Gen. Manuel Noriega was the de facto ruler of Panama until his capture by U.S. forces in 1989.

item.title: Airlines Are Canceling Flights After U.S. Closes Airspace Over the Caribbean
item.description: The Federal Aviation Administration cited “safety-of-flight risks” in restricting the U.S.-controlled airspace as a result of the military operation in Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: Mark Walker
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Several air carriers, including American Airlines, had canceled flights to destinations in the Caribbean early on Saturday.

item.title: Venezuela’s Interim Leader Defies Trump and Calls Maduro the ‘Only President’
item.description: President Trump said that Venezuela’s new leader, Delcy Rodríguez, would help the United States run Venezuela. She quickly said the opposite.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.media:credit: Brittainy Newman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Delcy Rodríguez, who was Venezuela’s vice president under President Nicolás Maduro, was sworn in as interim president on Saturday, the U.S. said.

item.title: Trump Shares Photo of Captured Nicolás Maduro, Blindfolded and Handcuffed
item.description: The Venezuelan president and his wife were flown out of Caracas by helicopter to the U.S.S. Iwo Jima, a warship taking them to New York.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Ahn
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Is It Legal for U.S. to ‘Run’ Venezuela After Maduro’s Capture? Here’s What to Know.
item.description: The operation revives disputes over the legality of the 1989 Panama intervention, enhanced by President Trump’s vow to “run” Venezuela and Nicolás Maduro’s formal status as president.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.media:description: Smoke rising from Fuerte Tiuna, a military complex in Caracas, on Saturday morning. U.S. troops captured President Nicolás Maduro in a raid of a safe house.

item.title: What We Know About the U.S. Operation in Venezuela and Maduro’s Capture
item.description: U.S. forces carried out an audacious raid on the country’s capital, seizing President Nicolás Maduro. President Trump said the United States now intends to “run” Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: Aimee Ortiz, Hannah Ziegler and Yan Zhuang

item.title: Venezuela broadcasts messages of resistance from Maduro loyalists after the U.S. attack.
item.dc:creator: Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
item.media:description: Supporters of President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela gathered in Caracas, Venezuela, on Saturday, after the United States captured him in an early morning raid.

item.title: What to Know About Venezuela’s Oil Industry as Trump Plans U.S. Intervention
item.description: Venezuela claims to have more than 300 billion barrels in the ground, but it is only producing about one million barrels a day.
item.dc:creator: Stanley Reed

item.title: World Leaders React With Shock and Skepticism After U.S. Captures Maduro
item.description: Several Latin American leaders responded with anger, while European leaders were more cautious. President Trump’s audacious raid drew support, too.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: A burned vehicle at one of the sites in Caracas, the capital of Venezuela, struck on Saturday in U.S. attacks.

item.title: Inside ‘Operation Absolute Resolve,’ the U.S. Effort to Capture Maduro
item.description: The tactically precise operation successfully extracted Mr. Maduro with no loss of American life, a result heralded by President Trump amid larger questions about the legality and rationale for the U.S. actions in Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes, Tyler Pager and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: A Timeline of Rising Tension Between the U.S. and Venezuela
item.description: The Trump administration has for months increased pressure on the Maduro government through a series of diplomatic and military maneuvers.
item.dc:creator: Isabela Espadas Barros Leal and Genevieve Glatsky
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A mural of President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela in the nation’s capital, Caracas.

item.title: Vance Justifies Capture as Bringing Maduro to Justice
item.description: Mr. Maduro has “multiple indictments in the United States for narcoterrorism,” the vice president said.
item.dc:creator: Adam Sella
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Vice President JD Vance took to social media on Saturday to assert that the United States’ capture of President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela was legal.

item.title: Trump Avoids Congressional Approval for Maduro’s Capture, and Democrats Raise Alarms
item.description: Democrats raised constitutional concerns and said the Trump administration had misrepresented its goals in Venezuela, while most Republicans cheered the action.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Kriston Jae Bethel for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Andy Kim, Democrat of New Jersey, accused Secretary of State Marco Rubio and Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth of having “blatantly” lied to Congress about the administration’s goals in Venezuela.
